customers that had more stringent compliance and regulatory requirements and sensitive data and workloads so
customers that wanted to take advantage of the AWS cloud but to do so in a fashion that still maintained their
compliance against any government regulations or more stringent compliance requirements they had that may have
prohibited them from using some of our other regions on our platform we built and launched the region in August of
2011 with a core US government customer in mind and NASA JPL as Theresa
mentioned this morning was was was one of the primary drivers but we also recognized that there were a number of
government agencies across the federal government as well as state and local governments that also had more
additional requirements in terms of compliance that may have prevented them from leveraging our other regions
specifically those regions in the US so we embarked upon building what then
became AWS gov cloud us with a core focus on compliance right so how do we
help government agencies adopt cloud while still maintaining their compliance and we'll spend some time here in a few
slides talking about some of the more specific compliance features of gov cloud but we looked at it not just to
adhere to things like ITAR which is the US government's international traffic in arms regulation mainly focused on export
control for defense and military related data and information but we we looked out on the horizon and recognized that
whether it's FedRAMP or some of the requirements from DISA or some of the requirements from our Department of
Justice customers right we needed to build a region that met all of those requirements to allow those customers to
maintain their compliance while leveraging the cloud now as I mention go
cloud is a region right but there are a number of individual characteristics and features of gov cloud that distinguish
it from all of our other regions to include our other US regions one of the foundational elements that is relatively
unique to gov cloud is the fact that as I mentioned on the previous slide it is an isolated region and what that means is from the
standpoint of physical and logical isolation we provide data network and
machine separation from all of our other regions on our platform to include our other u.s. regions and with that
typically materializes in for customers that use AWS today is if you log into
our management console you'll notice in the top right hand corner there's this section that's called a region selector
it's a little drop-down you click it and it will give you a list of regions that you can select to deploy your workloads
or host your data for those of you who use AWS today you will notice that gov cloud does not show up in that list and
the fundamental reason why it doesn't is because of the isolation that you need
to go cloud so when we looked at meeting some of the more stringent requirements that our customers had in the government
we recognized that we needed a region that gave customers the ability to maintain compliance in a relatively
isolated and segmented manner so that they didn't violate any export control regulations or violate any of their
compliance requirements from a US federal government perspective beyond
that isolation we also went a step further and for all customers or
partners that are qualified to access gov you'll get a separate unique set of credentials that you will use to access
the region in addition to the isolation we wanted to ensure that customers could
further segment and restrict access to their more sensitive environments typically those environments and
workloads that are hosted in the gov client region and then beyond just the isolation in the separate credentials we
also built a standalone management console for gov cloud it looks smells
fields operates just like the standard management console for the traditional a

and you log in to your gov cloud management console right you can't interact with any other region when
you're deploying those workloads and building those applications and running those applications and gov cloud via the
management console you're only interacting with those resources and apps in the region one of
the other fundamental differences with gov cloud is it is a region that is fully managed by AWS personnel that are
us persons on US soil that becomes vitally important for our customers that have to deal with
regulations such as ITAR or sieges right or some of the DoD requirements that
necessitate us persons only access so from an AWS perspective that means
not just our data center engineers and our dentists data center operators but our support teams our service teams in
any of the system engineers that support the government are all US persons on US soil and then beyond the US persons
element we we typically hear from customers that they refer to gov cloud as our community cloud and the reason

Gulf loud region there's a separate vetting and validation process that we conduct on the backend all customers
have to adhere to the terms and conditions of use of gov cloud and assuming that they pass that validation
and verification right because we control who gets access to the region many customers and many partners refer

US soil and then finally both the person and the organization that that person
works for cannot be barred from handling export control data as determined by the

holders or all users requesting access to go floud does not have any violations
on file with the US State Department for export control that is non-negotiable so
as part of our validation and verification process when we onboard customers to the region we will one that check and if we do find violations we
will stop the process and prohibit access to gov that applies regardless of if you're
